fullProgramDescription: The Computer Science program at UCLA is designed to give students a broad background in the theory, design, and application of computer systems. The program provides a foundation in computer science theory, algorithms, data structures, programming languages, computer architecture, and software engineering. Students also gain practical experience through coursework and projects.
shortProgramDescription: UCLA's Computer Science B.S. provides a foundation in computer science theory and application, preparing students for careers or further study.
classHighlights: The program requires foundational courses in Programming (CS 31, CS 32), Computer Organization (CS 33, CS 35L), and Data Structures (CS 180).
Students also take courses in Algorithms (CS 180), Computer Architecture (CS 133), Operating Systems (CS 111), and Software Engineering (CS 151).
Additional required courses cover Theory of Computation (CS 181), Machine Learning (CS 181), and Computer Networks (CS 118).
Electives allow students to explore specialized areas such as Artificial Intelligence, Computer Vision, and Human-Computer Interaction.
The program includes coursework in mathematics, including Discrete Mathematics (MATH 61), Linear Algebra (MATH 115A), and Probability and Statistics (MATH 170A, MATH 170E).
Students must also complete a set of breadth requirements, including courses in science, engineering, and writing.
learningOutcomes: Apply computer science theory and principles to design and implement software systems.
Analyze algorithms for correctness and efficiency.
Understand computer systems, architecture, and organization.
Use mathematics and probability to solve computing problems.
Communicate technical concepts in written and oral form.
Evaluate ethical, societal, and global implications of technology.
additionalInformation: The program is designed for students to be declared in the major by the start of their sophomore year. Students must meet specific GPA requirements and complete required preparation courses.
